duck: lysine definition: a crystalline essential amino acid C^^6^^H^^14^^N^^2^^O^^2^^ obtained from the hydrolysis of various proteins.
Acetyllysine - Acetyllysine is an acetyl-derivative of the amino acid lysine.
Deamination - Deamination is the removal of an amine group from a molecule.
Lysine (abbreviated as Lys or K) is an α-amino acid with the chemical formula HO<sub>2</sub>CCH(NH<sub>2</sub>)(CH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>.
Lysine price-fixing conspiracy - The lysine price-fixing conspiracy was an organized effort during the mid-1990s to raise the price of the animal feed additive lysine.
Lysine (abbreviated as Lys or K) is an α-amino acid with the chemical formula HO<sub>2</sub>CCH(NH<sub>2</sub>)(CH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>.
Saccharopine - Saccharopine is an intermediate in the metabolism of amino acid lysine.

'Lysine' (abbreviated as 'Lys' or 'K')<ref></ref> is an α-amino acid with the
chemical formula
HO<sub>2</sub>CCH(NH<sub>2</sub>)(CH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>NH<sub>2</sub>. It
is an essential amino acid for humans. Lysine's codons are AAA and AAG.

Lysine is a base, as are arginine and histidine. The ε-amino group often
participates in hydrogen bonding and as a general base in catalysis. (The ε-
amino group (NH<sub>3</sub><sup>+</sup>) is attached to the fifth carbon
beginning from the α-carbon, which is attached to the carboxyl (C=OOH) group.<r-
ef>[http://www.biology.arizona.edu/biochemistry/problem_sets/aa/Lysine.html
Lysine.] The Biology Project, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular
Biophysics, University of Arizona.</ref>)

Common posttranslational modifications include methylation of the ε-amino
group, giving methyl-, dimethyl-, and trimethyllysine. The latter occurs in
calmodulin. Other posttranslational modifications at lysine residues include
acetylation and ubiquitination. Collagen contains hydroxylysine, which is
derived from lysine by lysyl hydroxylase. O-Glycosylation of hydroxylysine
residues in the endoplasmic reticulum or Golgi apparatus is used to mark
certain proteins for secretion from the cell.
